verses.text: The Angel of the LORD went up from Gilgal to Bochim, and he said, "I brought you up out of Egypt and led you into the land that I swore to give to your fathers. I said, 'I will never break my covenant with you.'"
verses.comment: The 'Angel of the LORD' is rendered as in the Hebrew; 'Bochim' is transliterated, meaning 'weepers.'

verses.text: And you shall make no covenant with the inhabitants of this land. You shall break down their altars. But you have not obeyed my command. What is this you have done?
verses.comment: 'Altars' refers to pagan shrines; command rendered literally as 'voice.'

verses.text: So I also said, 'I will not drive them out before you, but they shall be as thorns in your sides, and their gods shall be a snare to you.'"
verses.comment: 'Thorns in your sides' is a Hebrew idiom kept literal; 'snare' rendered as in Hebrew.

verses.text: When the Angel of the LORD spoke these words to all the people of Israel, the people lifted up their voices and wept.
verses.comment: Literal translation of 'lifted up their voices.'

verses.text: So they called the name of that place Bochim, and they sacrificed there to the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Bochim' is transliterated, meaning 'weepers.'

verses.text: When Joshua had sent the people away, the sons of Israel each went to his inheritance to possess the land.
verses.comment: 'Sons of Israel' preserves literal Hebrew idiom for 'children of Israel.'

verses.text: The people served the LORD all the days of Joshua, and all the days of the elders who outlived Joshua, who had seen all the great work that the LORD had done for Israel.
verses.comment: 'Great work' translates Hebrew 'all the great deeds.'

verses.text: Then Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the LORD, died at the age of one hundred and ten years.
verses.comment: 'Son of Nun' preserved for accuracy.

verses.text: And they buried him within the territory of his inheritance in Timnath-heres, in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.
verses.comment: Timnath-heres is transliterated from Hebrew.

verses.text: After all that generation had also been gathered to their fathers, another generation arose after them who did not know the LORD or the work that he had done for Israel.
verses.comment: 'Gathered to their fathers' is a Hebrew idiom for dying. 'Know' means relational knowledge.

verses.text: Then the sons of Israel did what was evil in the sight of the LORD and served the Baals.
verses.comment: 'Baals' refers to Canaanite gods; term transliterated.

verses.text: They abandoned the LORD, the God of their fathers, who had brought them out of the land of Egypt, and followed other gods, from among the gods of the peoples who were around them, and bowed down to them. And they provoked the LORD to anger.
verses.comment: 'Abandoned' is sometimes translated as 'forsook.'

verses.text: They abandoned the LORD and served Baal and the Ashtaroth.
verses.comment: 'Ashtaroth' is transliterated; refers to Canaanite fertility goddesses.

verses.text: So the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he gave them over to plunderers who plundered them; and he sold them into the hand of their enemies all around, so that they could no longer stand before their enemies.
verses.comment: Literal translation of 'anger ... was kindled.'

verses.text: Wherever they went out, the hand of the LORD was against them for harm, as the LORD had spoken and as the LORD had sworn to them. And they were in great distress.
verses.comment: 'Hand of the LORD' is a Hebrew idiom kept literal.

verses.text: Then the LORD raised up judges, who saved them out of the hand of those who plundered them.
verses.comment: 'Judges' refers to tribal leaders or deliverers.

verses.text: Yet they did not listen even to their judges, for they prostituted themselves after other gods and bowed down to them. They turned aside quickly from the way in which their fathers had walked, who obeyed the commandments of the LORD; they did not do so.
verses.comment: 'Prostituted themselves' translates the Hebrew idiom for spiritual unfaithfulness.

verses.text: Whenever the LORD raised up judges for them, the LORD was with the judge, and he saved them from the hand of their enemies all the days of the judge; for the LORD had compassion because of their groaning under those who oppressed and afflicted them.
verses.comment: 'Had compassion' is literal from Hebrew.

verses.text: But whenever the judge died, they turned back and became more corrupt than their fathers, going after other gods, to serve them and bow down to them. They did not cease from their practices or their stubborn ways.
verses.comment: 'Practices' refers to idolatrous customs; 'stubborn ways' is literal.

verses.text: So the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he said, "Because this nation has transgressed my covenant that I commanded their fathers and have not obeyed my voice,
verses.comment: 'Obeyed my voice' is literal Hebrew idiom for 'obeyed my commands.'

verses.text: I will also not drive out before them any of the nations that Joshua left when he died,
verses.comment: Literal translation.

verses.text: in order to test Israel by them, whether they will keep the way of the LORD to walk in it as their fathers kept it, or not."
verses.comment: 'Test' means 'to prove' or 'to try.'

verses.text: So the LORD left those nations, not driving them out quickly. And he did not give them into the hand of Joshua.
verses.comment: The subject (the LORD) is supplied for clarity.
